Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Black Cobalt Oxide Nanowire Arrays: Synthesis, Properties, and Energy Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The objective of this CAREER project supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry (SSMC) program in DMR is to investigate the fundamental properties of Co3O4 nanowire arrays and their applications for efficient solar energy harvesting and conversion. Co3O4 is an exciting material for energy & environmental science. It has one of the highest turnover frequencies for the oxidation of water. It is a high-capacity anode material for Li-ion batteries. Black cobalt oxide is also one of the most promising materials for high-temperature solar selective absorbers. Nanowire arrays have the structural advantages of large surface area, enhanced light absorption, and efficient separation and collection of photo-excited charge carriers over thin film or bulk counterparts. The PI's group has recently discovered a facile method for growing mesoporous single-crystalline Co3O4 nanowire arrays and demonstrated their superior performance as an anode in Li-ion batteries. This project is to investigate their fundamental growth mechanism, study their basic electrical, optical and catalytic properties and explore their applications for the oxygen evolution reaction, photoelectrochemical cells, and solar selective absorbers.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Cobalt oxide is an exciting and versatile material for solar energy harvesting and storage. This project is focused on understanding the chemistry of cobalt oxide nanowire arrays, which is expected to open up substantial opportunities in splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen molecules, as well as converting solar energy into heat. This project also involves integrating the PI's research interests in energy materials with the educational goal of building a strong multi-tiered energy education program. For example, the PI will integrate the research on solar selective absorbers with hands-on activities of building solar cookers for elementary and middle school teachers and students. Other activities consist of: (1) developing a new freshman seminar class in sustainable energy technologies, (2) modifying the existing general chemistry curriculum, (3) developing research modules for the Ohio Consortium for Undergraduate Research: Research Experience to Enhance Learning (OCUR-REEL), and (4) recruiting minority and women undergraduate students to take part in research on energy materials. Through these activities, the PI hopes to build a solid education program on energy & environmental science, which is vital for the sustainable development of our society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An effective electrocatalyst for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) can enhance the energy efficiency of water electrolysis for hydrogen production. Extensive research efforts have been invested in developing inexpensive and efficient OER electrocatalysts that have sufficient stability in prolonged exposure to oxidizing conditions.

In this NSF-supported project, we reported the first preparation of mesoporous Ni-doped cobalt oxide nanowire arrays in solution and demonstrated their high-performance electrocatalytic properties.

 

Another major accomplishment of this project is the invention of potassium-air (K-air) battery. Metal air batteries are the most energy dense electrochemical power sources. For example, fully developed and optimally packaged Li-air batteries can exceed specific energy of 2000 Wh/kg (theoretical 5200 Wh/kg). The novelty of a K-air battery is the introduction of one-electron redox process through the stabilization of superoxide anions. The K-air battery effectively provides better-than-Li-ion battery performance at less-than-lead-acid-battery price.

This project has also enabled important progress on large-area MoS2 growth, doping and heterostructures for semiconductor devices. One of the main constraining factors in conventional semiconductor technology is the requirement to closely match lattice constants and manage strain to prevent dislocation formation. These factors limit the combination of materials and functions that can be achieved with semiconductor heterostructures. MoS2 is a 2-dimensional (2D) layered semiconductor, which gives us an opportunity to go beyond these constraints to create a class of multi-dimensional heterostructure materials and devices that combine 2D layered materials and traditional 3D semiconductors. These new heterojunctions have structural, electronic, and optical properties that have not been explored before and could be completely different from traditional 3D semiconductor heterojunctions. This represents a new area of research with great potential for new scientific understanding as well as technological applications.

This project has provided valuable opportunities for undergraduate researchers and graduate students to develop research skills and to pursue entrepreneurship. They have received notable recognitions including a 2014-2015 Fulbright U.S. Student Award. Based on the K-air battery invention, a team formed from 5 graduate students in the PI’s lab and one student from the Fisher business school won 1st Place at the 2014 Ohio State Business Competition, and the $100,000 DOE Clean Energy Prize at the Rice Business Plan competition. Two graduate students have been selected in the Forbes Magazine 30 under 30 for the KAir battery technology and their entrepreneurship.
